STATEMENT: Perichondral bone: present
Form of nasal: with well-developed dorsal and ventral lamellae
Anterior shelf of frontal: ventrally expanded with straight margin
Number of anal-fin pterygiophores in prehaemal space (anterior to haemal spine of first caudal vertebra): none
Esterase la: absent
Overall morphology of the opercle: a broad, roughly triangular bony lamina
Ethmoid cartilage extension: lateral portion of ethmoid cartilage without posterior extension in all siluriforms except Diplomystidae
Transverse occipital crests: crests tilted obliquely backward, expanded onto supraoccipital process
Hypobranchial 4 cartilage: Present
Number of branchiostegal rays: seven

The radius is thus not rod shaped as originally reconstructed by Long (1989:fig. 11a), with approximately only a third of it visible, if its shape was similar to that of other Carboniferous rhizodontids.:
Ilium, bevis fossa, shape and orientation: arched ventrally-opening posteriorly-expanding to a width approximately 50% of its length
Total lateral-line scale count: mean: 142 (range: 130‚Äì168)
Anteroventral margin of lateral ethmoid: anterior margin straight and oblique
Metatarsal IV:: nearly the same mid-shaft diameter as metatarsal III

(G10.) Multiple jointing of pectoral radials: absent

EOD tetraphasic: EOD of mature specimens with two (sometimes one or three) phases

Second pharyngobranchial: extends mesially to about the same level as the first pharyngobranchial and the first and second epibranchials in siluriforms
Form of dorsal tip of maxilla: dorsal portion of maxilla in form of flat, medially-directed plate

A patch of about twenty conical teeth on endopterygoids and basibranchial 2: present
Metatarsal III, proximal end:: backs metatarsals II and IV posteroventrally, resulting in a T-shaped proximal profile
Spacing and form of teeth in outer dentary tooth row: teeth in anterior portion outer row of dentary much larger and more widely spaced apart than other teeth on jaw

The tibial articular surface faces anteroventrally and the fibular posterolaterally; the boundary between consists of a perichondral strip (otherwise known only in Ichthyostega), and both surfaces fit closely to the proximal epipodial heads.:
